title-group.article-title: Nutrition Support of Neonatal Patients at Risk for Necrotizing Enterocolitis
title-group.subtitle: Response to Fallon et al (2012)

body.p: With interest, we read the article by Fallon et al1 on nutrition support of neonatal patients at risk for necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC). The incidence of NEC and its attendant mortality and morbidities remain high despite general improvement in neonatal care. Nutrition, either parenteral or enteral, is a key component in both the occurrence and management of NEC. Therefore, we are very pleased with the effort of the authors (reviewing 1335 abstracts) to review the literature on the relation of nutrition with NEC.

Every literature search strategy depends heavily on the selection of keywords and limitations. Although the authors describe their selection for the 5 questions raised, it is unclear what the authors imply by their specification that “pertinent literature within the past 10 years, without restriction to the evidence type.”

In question 4 concerning the role of certain nutrients in the prevention or predisposition of NEC, the authors conclude, based on 1 randomized controlled trial by Poindexter et al,2 that there is strong evidence that glutamine supplementation cannot be recommended for infants at risk for NEC. We strongly disagree with this conclusion for the following reasons. First, the incidence of NEC was not the primary aim of the multicenter trial by Poindexter et al.2 Therefore, it is not justified to use the data as “strong” evidence for this contention. In addition, the quality of the trial was quite poor, as reviewed by us and others3,4 (eg, the extra parenteral supplementation of glutamine replaced other, in part essential, amino acids in order to have an isonitrogeneous amino acid solution). Second, glutamine was supplemented by the parenteral route, which has very different effects than by the enteral route. By the enteral route, around 70% of glutamine is used in first pass,5 and although none of the trials on enteral glutamine had NEC as the primary outcome, some studies on enteral glutamine supplementation showed positive effects on clinical end points.4,6-8 Third, in studies in cell cultures and animals, favorable effects of enteral supplementation of glutamine were found on the modulation of stress-induced intestinal injury, which plays a role in the susceptibility to develop NEC.9,10 Fourth, low plasma concentrations of glutamine have been associated with a higher incidence of NEC.11

In conclusion, although enteral glutamine supplementation has not been shown to prevent NEC, there is no strong evidence that enteral glutamine supplementation may not be beneficial for neonatal patients, especially extremely low birth weight and extremely preterm infants.
